So our problem is to categorise general Web videos of uncontrolled contents, so the IT is text, taxonomy based and multiple labels are allowed for each single video.
This is a challenging problem because we lack of high quality labeled data for training.
So in this work we propose a method of pairwise combination of multiple noisy different data sources and we propose this Treaty of Fusion.

Approach for further, if you start training single classifiers, so this approach naturally takes this hierarchical taxonomy structure into consideration so that it can help filtering out noises from the training data and we achieve a state of the art results on a very large scale YouTube video data set an.
For more details, please come to our post sections.
Thank you.
Good afternoon, I'm Julian Yarkoni and I'll be presenting work done with Charles Foulkes and Alexander Eiler at UCI called covering trees and lower bounds.
Quadratic assignment.

This paper concerns reweighting methods and their application to correspondence problems, reweighting methods, or a set of techniques which decompose a hard optimization problem into a collection of easier problems and then adjust the parameters of the subproblems to force them to agree on a common solution are well known.
Example of this is to break up a Markov random field into a set of trees, each of which can be solved using dynamic programming.
Variational parameters are used to force the subproblems.
Sharon answer.
True weighted belief propagation is an example of an algorithm optimizing these parameters.
At our poster, you'll be able to see an alternative approach which rather than using a collection of trees, uses a single covering tree.
And includes each edge of the original graph once and only once, but adds copies of nodes as needed.
The covering tree is fewer parameters than this collection of trees, but with only one covering tree is used an we preserve the same bound as tree weighted belief propagation.
One problem using belief propagation based methods for assignment is that is difficult to enforce the one to one matching constraint.
At our poster, you'll be able to see a new technique to enforce this one to one construct efficiently.
We call bottleneck assignment rounding.
This takes advantage of the min marginals given by the covering tray, which are estimates of the minimum cost condition on a particular assignment.
We use these min marginals to generate a sequence of bipartite matching problems whose solution gives a one to one assignment with a tighter lower bound.
We demonstrate that this gives a higher accuracy.
Correspondences in matching experiments.
And it's OM log N 2.
Hi, I'm carsie Kalahari this is joint work with Chris Russell and Phillip talks with.
University so conditional random fields have been used in vision since early 80s, but the problem of learning parameters in this framework has been largely unsolved problem.
Two previous previous methods to address this problem can be broadly classified into two methods.
The maximum likelihood methods and the Max margin learning methods.
So popular example of.
Maximum likelihood method is pseudo likelihood where you approximate the conditional of the true label given the data using local partition functions.
It's a great method.
It's easy to compute, but it can lead to poor accuracy in certain cases.
On the other hand, Max margin.
Learning methods eliminate the partition function by taking a difference of the conditional of the ground truth label and every other possible labeling.
This is a great discriminative approach which has shown excellent results, but it is only applicable to a limited class of multi label problems.

So we in our method we try and exploit the advantages of both these methods by decomposing the problem into a small set of trees or chains or scan lines which are essentially tractable graph structures.
And then propose Max margin learning on these graph structures.
So if you want to learn parameters in a smart way, come and see a poster later.
Thank you.
OK, thank you.
Now we want to do two things with the same applause.
We want to thank Dima Damon for wrangling the poster presenters and also thank all the presenters and the speakers in the sparsity in convex optimization sessions.
